posts.name: RoboGeek
posts.cooked:
Just came across an Instagram reel of team 1100‚Äôs interesting way of attaching bumpers, looks like thunderhex.

Just wanted to give them some exposure.

link_counts.title: FRC 1100 - Inverse Polarity on Instagram: "üö®BOX BOX, BOX BOX üö®"

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: Looks cool but I wonder what happens if they somehow mess up the threads on the bolt.

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked: ^ Bumper mounts that involve threads are often a recipe for a bad time. You‚Äôre either slowly threading a wing nut by hand, or using power tools on a relatively small fastener as much as 100 times in a season. You can use anti-seize, but for something that gets serviced so often I think a retention mechanism intended for that many cycles is worth the engineering effort.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
We were pretty happy with the 1678 solution that 111 used on their build this year (although we took a simplified manufacturing riff on the concept)

Yes it uses wing nuts, but you only have to loosen them about 6 to 8 turns, which was fine for the 4 total mounting points.  It probably would have been rather tedious for 8 mounting points though.

posts.name: SndMndBdy
posts.cooked:
We‚Äôve done something quite similar but we use flanged nuts and a magnetic nut driver.  The combination allows you to easily hold the nuts in the driver and then with a few quick turns you are able to mount the bumper securely.

I‚Äôd be concerned about using an impact driver for this operation, because I can easily see someone in a rush tightening it a bit too far and crushing the frame rail.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: I would only use threaded fasteners to mount the bumpers if they are easily replaced when damaged. May not be an issue with a wig nuts since is basically impossible not to feel cross threading or apply much torque, but when we used captive nuts and socket head screws we had to replace them a 2-3 times per season and we never used power tools on them.

posts.name: Nick Matthes
posts.cooked: 33 attaches our bumpers the same way. Basically take a 1/4-20 that bolts through the bottom of the chassis using an nylock or a jam nut and fasten it with a 1/2 thunderhex. If you mess up the threads on the bolt or the shaft, just replace the bolt or get a new thunderhex. This was our first year doing it and we were very satisfied.

posts.name: Jason DesMarais
posts.cooked:
Hey that‚Äôs us! I‚Äôm so glad you found our reel, the kids loved putting that one together and they‚Äôre thrilled to know its reaching people who are interested in robots.

We‚Äôve messed around with lots of bumper mounting solutions in our years, this was our first year with this particular solution. Despite the reel, what we actually ran at competition looked more like these:

IMG_7797 1920√ó2560 400 KB

IMG_7797 1920√ó2560 400 KB

IMG_7797 1920√ó2560 400 KB

This is just a 3D printed piece with a 1/4"-20 nut pressed into the bottom, and a 1/2" hex on top for tools and hands to work with. Personally, I liked the solution for our robot which had plenty of available horizontal space on the frame perimeter, and being able to use power tools made our bumper changes very quick. We had students start the threads by hand, then use a power driver with a moderate clutch setting to finish the assembly.

As others have mentioned, any time you ask any given nut and bolt to thread and unthread 100 times, stuff tends to go wrong. For us, we only had one cross thread all season, during which the 3D print broke free of the nut before it caused any real trouble. We simply replaced the bolts and swapped to a new set of bumper mounts, complete with new 1/4"-20 nuts, before our next competition and that second set brought us to the end of the year. We‚Äôll reevaluate our attachment method next year depending on what the robot looks like, but we were happy with this for 2024.

P.S. Having our kids find a post about us on CD was a highlight of the year, even if we had to lean on an F1 meme to do so

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked:
troy_dietz:

as much as 100 times in a season.

You much be going to more competitions than we are.

Our solution this year, which worked GREAT for us, was Rivnuts with threaded studs sticking out (loctite‚Äôd together), plus wing nuts.   A couple of people could swap out bumpers in about a minute.

[Yes, you can get rivstuds that combine the rivnut and threaded stud, but they‚Äôre harder to replace if you really have to, and the tooling is a lot harder to find and more expensive.]

posts.name: Jsteel
posts.cooked: I‚Äôm really surprised that more teams are not using the Plummer Industries bumper mounts.  They had a discount coupon in the Kit of Parts this year.  We‚Äôve used them for two years and they are very good.  No tools required - literally just takes a few seconds to push the button and engage the mount.

posts.name: Max Mayer
posts.cooked: This is what we used this year, they‚Äôre a breeze to put on and take off. After years of struggling with clips and other solutions they were 1000% worth the investment.

posts.name: MrBasse
posts.cooked:
We used a very similar method this year and had no issues.  We didn‚Äôt use power tools to apply them though.  Just finger tight plus a half turn with a wrench.  We took them off and put them on maybe a dozen times as we use reversible bumpers.

Since the ‚Äúnut‚Äù is aluminum the chances of ruining the bolt are pretty slim.  We did have to make some spare nuts just to be sure that we‚Äôd never need them.

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked:
Jsteel:

I‚Äôm really surprised that more teams are not using the Plummer Industries bumper mounts.

They‚Äôre pricey and it‚Äôs not entirely clear how they they‚Äôre intended to be used.  Plummer could really stand to have a video showing somebody using them on an actual bumper and robot frame.  If I told a kid ‚Äúhey, go check out this website to see if we should use this,‚Äù I think I‚Äôd get back ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt get it‚Äù and we‚Äôd move on to a different solution.

posts.name: Vaughn Khouri
posts.cooked:
Basically, less over-engineered version of the WCP bumper mount ?

image 650√ó650 57.9 KB

image 650√ó650 57.9 KB

image 650√ó650 57.9 KB

Bolts come up from under the frame rail, thread into the ‚Äúcones‚Äù, the wingnuts come down on top holding the bracket on top of the cones and its solid.

Honestly though can‚Äôt recommend the 971 / 1678 style enough. 5/16 glue studs, 4 mounts cut from 1/4 aluminum, and its solid as a rock. I made configurable CAD for them here , we CNCd out bumpers for the first time this year on 8033 and never going back.

posts.name: Joel
posts.cooked: We used a similar cocnept an it worked pretty good. Definitely easy to manufacture and a very rigid way of attaching the bumpers, never failed us

Our bumper attachment the last three years has been 10-32 bolts up through the chassis with brass knurled nuts to hold the bumper bracket down.

We‚Äôve been hitting north of 150 matches a season without thread issues.

Softer aluminum threads I‚Äôd be worried about, but this has been the easiest and more reliable method I‚Äôve found for mounting bumpers over 15+ years. Very rarely do we need to use tools if one of the nuts is put on too tight.

image 666√ó732 31.9 KB

image 666√ó732 31.9 KB

image 666√ó732 31.9 KB

CyberClone:

Honestly though can‚Äôt recommend the 971 / 1678 style enough. 5/16 glue studs, 4 mounts cut from 1/4 aluminum, and its solid as a rock. I made configurable CAD for them here , we CNCd out bumpers for the first time this year on 8033 and never going back.

My team used Citrus-style mounts this year, but we struggled to attach our studs robustly, so it‚Äôs really cool to see how you guys did yours!

For your bumpers, it seems like the studs are held in place by a T-nut on the inside surface‚Äîit looks difficult to grip either the stud or the nut, so how do you get those tightened all the way down? Does the T-nut protrude from the wood once you‚Äôre done?

Also, how did the box joints plus metal brackets in the corners work out for you guys?

posts.name: Vaughn Khouri
posts.cooked:
Figuring out how to stop the stud from unscrewing is the main challenge with citrus mounts, and we screwed it up first too (red locktite is not good enough lol). Luckily, the solution is pretty simple in the form of the adhesive studs from McMaster.

Essentially, the studs get held in from the back once they are tight with 3 wood screws, through the outermost holes in the stud. To get them tight in the first place, you thread it in first by hand, then put on two hex nuts and back them into each other with a wrench until tight. You can then use a wrench on both to torque down on the bolt until the T-nut is pulled tight.

We use Baltic Birch so the T-nut generally has no issue recessing itself with enough torque. However, if you are using a harder wood, it might make sense to cut a small recess for it, maybe like 0.1 depth. The reason why I didn‚Äôt is because it gives you just a little bit more stiffness on the stud if the wood is squeezed around the T nut.

The box joints are great, especially since you can CNC them pretty easily. The sauce in this design is that the brackets are fully custom. You can order these from Fabworks in 1/8 5052, pre-bent (and countersinked!), or you can make them yourself with a break or a hammer and some patience. By doing this, you can get the inner bracket, board, and outer bracket screw holes to all line up:

Bumper Assembly (2) 3296√ó2547 1.94 MB

Bumper Assembly (2) 3296√ó2547 1.94 MB

Bumper Assembly (2) 3296√ó2547 1.94 MB

This makes it pretty much bomb-proof because there‚Äôs really nothing to bend. The only way you‚Äôll realistically break your bumpers is by snapping the wood.

One note: make sure to measure the thickness of your plywood before exporting and ordering the brackets, and set the configuration. 3/4 is considered ‚Äúnominal‚Äù and is almost never actually 3/4. Accurate thickness is required to make the holes line up, but it pays off with the strength of the construction once you put it together.

Overall we were happy with these style mounts this year. The only real note I have is if you have a very large frame, you might want to support it along more then 4 points. One extra point on the other two sides is great to avoid stuff like this: Screenshot 2024-05-05 at 11.41.07 PM 1452√ó1128 130 KB

Screenshot 2024-05-05 at 11.41.07 PM 1452√ó1128 130 KB

Screenshot 2024-05-05 at 11.41.07 PM 1452√ó1128 130 KB

Let me know if you have any other questions!

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
We used Home Depot 7-ply ‚ÄúBaltic birch‚Äù for our first three events and couldn‚Äôt get them to last all 20 matches, even after adding metal corners which we‚Äôve never needed before. I describe the failure mode as ‚Äúmelting‚Äù the wood.

Swapped to 13¬±ply furniture shop cast-off Baltic Birch for EBR and finally made it through the weekend without an emergency bumper repair. Bumpers also weighed about 4lbs more each.

I haven‚Äôt needed to go for the specialized adhesive  studs that Citrus recommends, threading a bolt into a standard t-nut has held fine with loctite (given that we use standard (non-locking) nuts right now), and I can source it all at home Depot. However, YMMV, especially if nylon locknuts are in the mix. (The T-nut should not noticeably protrude on the interior)

I like the metal sandwich corner architecture, definitely appreciate how well the load gets spread.

posts.name: Henry Becker
posts.cooked:
We have used 1/4" studs pressed into 1/4" aluminum plate that is screwed to the corners of our MK4i. The bumpers use the metal sandwich design with 2x2x1/8" steel angle on the outside and custom welded steel brackets on the inside that are held to the studs with 1/4" stainless nylock nuts. With all of this steel, our bumpers came in at 15.0 at both regionals and worlds. We used steel because the aluminum we used last year broke on us multiple times during the season. We had not a single bumper issue this year. GroupMe_202456_93311 1920√ó2560 908 KB

GroupMe_202456_93311 1920√ó2560 908 KB
